description: Beginning on March 22, Gabon is implementing a country-wide curfew from 7:30pm to 6:00am.

On April 27, the Gabonese government announced that the state of extended curfew for 15 days through to May 11. Restriction measures introduced under the state of emergency remain in place including a nationwide curfew from 19:30 to 06:00 (local time) especially in Libreville and the nearby communities of Owendo, Akanda, Ntoum, and Pointe Denis.
Beginning on March 22, Gabon is implementing a country-wide curfew from 7:30pm to 6:00am. Starting April 27, the curfew will last from 6pm to 6am.

On April 28, the Gabonese government eased measures in the Grand Libreville area, including the communes of Libreville, Owendo, Akanda, Ntoum, and the Pointe-Denis peninsula. The new measures replaced a total lockdown with a curfew between the hours of 17:00 and 07:00. Residents of Grand Libreville are to remain isolated from the rest of Gabon, with fines enforceable for violation of restrictions until next order.
On April 28, the Government of Gabon announced a Traffic ban between 6 p.m. and 6 a.m. throughout the whole of the national territory until next order.

On April 29, the Gabonese government announced in the capital, Libreville. Travelling within greater Libreville is now permitted between 6:00 am and 6:00 pm whilst the rest of Gabon is under travel ban.

On May 11, the Gabonese Government extended the national curfew. Gabon's state of emergency imposed amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic expires at midnight (local time) on May 11, but the government has confirmed Restrictions on movement, a nationwide curfew from 19:30 to 06:00
On June 18, the Gabonese Government extended the national curfew. All parts of the country are subject to a curfew between 6:00 pm and 6:00 am.
On July 1, the Gabonese Government announced a curfew that will remain in effect, but with reduced hours (20:00 to 05:00) until further order.

On October 26 the Gabonese government announced that people holding a Laissez-Passer (a pass issued to people carrying out essential services during curfew hours) will have to renew this via a new internet platform laissezpassercovid19@gouv.ga. Failure to comply with the measures would constitute a criminal offence and can lead to fines or community service."
On April 10, Gabonese president Ali Bongo declares a state of emergency.
The state of emergency declared on April 10 by Gabonese president Ali Bongo will end on May 11.
On October 7 the Gabonese government announced the Prolongation of State of Health Emergency for another 45 days until at least November 17.
On March 7 the Gabonese government instituted a Restriction for all international missions.
On March 7 the Gabonese government instituted a Restriction for all international missions.
On March 13 the government of Gabon suspended tourist visas from EU, China, South Korea and US till next order.
type_sub_cat: Visa restrictions (e.g. suspend issuance of visa)

description: On March 14, the government of Gabon announced that all land, sea and air borders have been closed indefinitely.
On March 16, Gabon restricts international travel to and from Gabon to one flight per week per airline.
On March 17 the Government of Gabon announced a Restriction of international flights to and from Gabon to one international flight per airline per week.
On March 20, Gabon closes all its land, sea, and air borders.

On July 1, the Gabonese government announced an end to the International flights suspension. Commercial air travel may resume. Two international flights per airline per week will be permitted. Land and sea borders will remain closed to travellers

On September 23, the Gabonese government announced that, flight restrictions have eased to allow three international flights per airline, per week. Land and sea borders are closed. All Gabon diplomatic missions abroad are prohibited from issuing entry visas to Gabon. Additional health/documents will be required upon arrival passengers must provide proof of a negative COVID-19 test taken within the last 14 days. Foreign nationals wishing to leave Gabon, need to obtain a letter of permission (“authorisation de sortie”) from the Gabonese Government and have proof of a negative corona virus test prior to departure.
On October 16, the Gabonese government announced that  land and sea borders will remain closed
On March 7, the Gabonese Government announced that Covid-19 related health expenses are reimbursed by the government.

description: On August 25, the Gabonese government announced that a large quantity of medical equipment was distributed to the various health structures of Haut Ogooué and Ogooué Lolo. These are 200 beds, 200 mattresses, 200 thermo flashes, 2,000 charlottes, 600 visors, 2,000 gowns, 2,000 overshoes, 1 million surgical masks, 20,000 N95 masks, 20,000 gloves, 600 protective glasses and 110 litres of hydro-alcoholic gel.

description: On April 12, The Gabonese Government announced lock-down in the capital. Authorities announced the implementation of a 15-day lock down in the capital Libreville, and the nearby communes of Owendo, Akanda, Ntoum, and Pointe Denis as of Monday, April 13. As such, residents are only permitted to leave their homes for limited reasons, such as obtaining essential goods or seeking healthcare. Those working in industries deemed essential by the government are exempt from the measures.
Starting April 15, everyone must wear a mask in public.

description: On April 27, the Gabonese government announced companies should continue to encourage telework for employees but may gradually return to business and administrative activities. Work hours must be limited to 7:30 am to 2:00 pm. Health control devices such as thermoflash devices, hand sanitizer, and masks must be placed at company and administrative office entrances. - Small businesses such as hair salons, garages, tire repair ships, and artisan workshops may begin to reopen subject to social distancing measures such as reductions in the numbers of staff and clients, the presence of disinfectants, and the wearing of masks. - Other commercial enterprises such as hardware stores, building and construction entities, and retailers of office supplies, furniture, and appliances, will gradually reopen with social distancing measures in place."
